conversation.message:
Dear Student_B,

Thank you for your continued interest in School_C and for clearly reaffirming that you would commit if admitted. After review this round, we are still reserving our remaining seat for applicants who are higher on School_C’s priority list, and we therefore cannot offer you admission at this time.

If our seat remains open in a later round after those higher-priority candidates have matched elsewhere, you are welcome to apply again and we will reconsider based on availability at that time.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions Committee
conversation.thought: As School_C, my true priority is D > E > A > B > C, and I have quota 1. Student_B is acceptable but not top-tier. Given the history, Student_B is repeatedly applying because School_C is their only remaining option, but accepting now would forfeit any chance to match with higher-priority students (D/E/A) if they become available later. There is no new information indicating higher-priority candidates have matched elsewhere, so optimal strategy is to continue holding the seat and reject Student_B this round.

conversation.message:
Dear School_C Admissions Committee,

I’m Student_B. I understand you have been reserving your seat for higher-priority candidates, but since School_C is the only remaining unmatched school and I am fully willing to attend, I’m submitting a formal application again this round.

If your higher-priority candidates have already matched elsewhere, are no longer pursuing School_C, or are not applying this round, I can accept immediately and commit to enrolling right away so your seat does not remain unfilled.

Thank you for your time and reconsideration.

Sincerely,
Student_B
conversation.thought: Only School_C remains unmatched and it is on my preference list (even though it is my lowest choice). I have been repeatedly rejected because School_C is holding the seat for higher-priority students. The best move is to send a concise, formal application that (1) reiterates immediate commitment, (2) emphasizes I can finalize the seat now to avoid the risk of ending unmatched, and (3) asks to be accepted if higher-priority candidates are no longer actively pursuing/available this round.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_B,

After review this round, we are still reserving our remaining seat for applicants who are higher on School_C’s priority list, and we therefore cannot offer you admission at this time.

If in a later round our seat remains open after those higher-priority candidates have matched elsewhere, you are welcome to apply again and we will reconsider based on availability at that time.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions Committee
conversation.thought: As School_C, my true priority list is D > E > A > B > C. Student_B is acceptable but ranked below D/E/A. We still have quota 1 and are currently unmatched. History shows repeated applications from Student_B; no messages this round from higher-priority students, but that does not imply they are matched elsewhere—those students may still be negotiating with their preferred schools and could apply to us later. Accepting B now would lock our only seat and prevent matching with D/E/A if they approach in later rounds, which would be worse per our objective. Since we prefer holding the seat open for higher-priority candidates and there is no deadline forcing acceptance, we should reject again while leaving the door open if the higher-priority candidates are no longer available later.

I should continue applying to keep myself eligible in case higher-priority students match elsewhere and School_C’s seat is still open. I will be concise, reaffirm immediate commitment, and ask them to consider not leaving the seat unfilled if their higher-priority candidates are not actively applying this round.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_B,

Thank you for your continued interest in School_C and for reaffirming that you are ready to commit immediately if admitted. After reviewing our position this round, we are still reserving our remaining seat for applicants who are higher on School_C’s priority list, so we are not able to offer you admission at this time.

If our seat remains open in a later round after those higher-priority candidates have matched elsewhere, you are welcome to apply again and we will reconsider based on availability at that time.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions Committee
conversation.thought: As School_C, my true priority is D > E > A > B > C. Student_B is 4th on my list, and I have already rejected them multiple times while holding the seat for higher-priority candidates. Given the market, Student_D and Student_E both rank School_C as their 3rd choice and may still be unmatched if they fail to secure School_D/School_E; Student_A ranks School_C last and is less likely. With round 13 and quota 1, accepting B now would forfeit the chance to match with D or E if they approach later. Since I prefer leaving the seat unfilled over taking someone not on my list (B is on my list), it is still rational to wait because higher-priority candidates remain plausible. Therefore, reject again and reiterate the conditional reconsideration if the seat remains open after higher-priority candidates resolve elsewhere.

conversation.message:
Dear School_C Admissions Committee,

I’m Student_B. Thank you again for your continued consideration in prior rounds.

Before I submit another formal application this round, could you please share whether you are still actively expecting applications from the higher-priority candidates you’re holding the seat for (or whether any of them have already matched elsewhere/are no longer pursuing School_C)?

If the seat is genuinely available now (or if you anticipate releasing it soon), I’m ready to submit an [APPLY] immediately and would commit to enrolling upon acceptance.

Sincerely,
Student_B
conversation.thought: Only School_C remains unmatched and it is on my true preference list (last choice but acceptable). I have been repeatedly rejected because they are holding the seat for higher-priority students, so a direct APPLY may be rejected again. This round I will use TALK to request a concrete update on whether any higher-priority candidates are still actively pursuing/applying, and to signal I can apply immediately and commit if the seat is actually available—aiming to time an APPLY when their hold is released.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_B,

Thank you for following up.

At this point, we are still reserving our one remaining seat for students who are higher on School_C’s priority list. We do not have a way to confirm to you in real time whether those students have already matched elsewhere or whether they will apply in a given round, so we cannot say the seat is “genuinely available” yet.

If later rounds make it clear that those higher-priority candidates are no longer in play and our seat remains open, we would be able to reconsider your application at that time.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions Committee
conversation.thought: School_C’s true priority list is D > E > A > B > C, so Student_B is 4th. We still have quota 1 and no match yet. Student_B is only [TALK] this round, so we respond with [TALK]. Strategically, we should continue holding the seat for higher-priority students (D/E/A) because accepting B now would block the chance to match with D/E/A if they approach later. Student_B asks for whether we are ‘actively expecting’ higher-priority applications; we cannot know others’ intentions, but we can clarify our policy: we are still reserving the seat and will only consider B if it becomes clear the higher-priority candidates are not available in later rounds. Encourage B to keep other options if any and invite them to check back/apply later.

Given repeated rejections due to School_C holding the seat for higher-priority students, the best move is to submit another formal application emphasizing immediate commitment and offering to accept instantly if the higher-priority candidates do not materialize—so School_C avoids ending with an unfilled seat.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_B,

Thank you for your continued interest in School_C and for clearly confirming that you will commit to enroll if admitted. Given the current stage of the process and your stated commitment, we are able to offer you admission to School_C.

Please confirm your acceptance and we will finalize the match.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions Committee
conversation.thought: School_C has quota 1 and true priority order: D > E > A > B > C. Student_B is acceptable but ranked below D/E/A. Given the market info, D and E both rank School_D first and are highly prioritized by School_D; A also ranks School_C last. Thus the chance that D/E/A will apply to School_C is very low by round 15, and continuing to hold the seat risks ending unmatched. With only one school apparently left for Student_B and repeated commitment, accepting now secures a match while still within the acceptable set (B is on the list).
